meta.title: How Screen-Dependent Is Your Family?
meta.description: A judgment-free look at your family's relationship with screens — who's reaching for them, when, and why. Based on validated instruments from pediatric and media psychology research.
meta.intro:
This isn't about counting hours or feeling guilty. Screens are a tool — every family uses them. What matters is the pattern: who reaches for them, when, and what happens when they're not available.

Answer for your family as it actually is, not as you wish it were.

sources.name: ScreenQ — Composite Measure of Screen-Based Media Use (Hutton et al., 2020)
SCREENS-Q — Socio-Ecological Screen Media Questionnaire (Klakk et al., 2020)
PSUS — Parent Screen-Based Device Use Survey (2023)
PMUM — Problematic Media Use Measure (Domoff et al., 2019)
MEPA — Media Parenting Scale (Vacek et al., 2021)

questions.text: How does your child access screens?
questions.subtext: Think about what devices are available and how easily they can get to them.
questions.source: ScreenQ — device access is the strongest environmental predictor of screen time

options.text: They use ours when we hand it to them — no device of their own
There's a shared family tablet or TV they can ask to use
They have their own device and know where it is
Multiple devices within reach — TV, tablet, phone

questions.text: Is there usually a screen on in the background at home?
questions.subtext: TV playing while no one's actively watching, phone propped up during cooking, etc.
questions.source: SCREENS-Q — background media is a major unmeasured exposure source

options.text: No — screens are only on when someone's actively watching something
The TV is on during meals or while we get ready, but not all day
There's usually something playing — it's just how our house sounds
Multiple screens going at once is pretty normal for us

questions.text: Does your family have clear rules about when screens are and aren't allowed?
questions.source: MEPA — rule presence is a stronger predictor of healthy screen patterns than total hours

options.text: Yes — specific rules everyone knows (no screens at meals, time limits, etc.)
Some loose guidelines, but they flex depending on the day
Not really — screen time happens organically
We've tried rules but couldn't stick to them

questions.text: When you need to get something done — cooking, a work call, a shower — what happens?
questions.source: PSUS — screens-as-childcare is the most common parent-driven use pattern

options.text: My child plays on their own or another adult helps
Sometimes a screen, sometimes they find something else to do
A screen is my go-to — it's the most reliable way to buy time
I honestly can't get anything done without handing them a device

questions.text: During transitions — waiting rooms, restaurants, car rides — how do screens enter the picture?
questions.source: ScreenQ — use during waiting; PSUS — screens as transition management tool

options.text: We usually don't bring screens for these moments
For long waits we might bring something, but it's not automatic
I pre-load something before we leave — it's part of the routine
A screen comes out within the first few minutes, every time

questions.text: When your child is having a hard moment — meltdown, overtired, frustrated — what's your first move?
questions.source: PSUS — screens as mood regulation; PMUM-SF — mood regulation dependence marker

options.text: Comfort, talk through it, or give them space to feel it
Depends on the day — sometimes comfort, sometimes a screen
A screen usually calms things down fastest
A screen is the only thing that reliably works

questions.text: When your child is on a screen, what are you usually doing?
questions.source: ScreenQ — co-viewing domain; MEPA — active mediation subscale

options.text: Watching or playing with them — we talk about what's happening
Nearby, sometimes watching, sometimes doing my own thing
Using the time to get other things done — that's kind of the point
I'm not sure what they're watching most of the time

questions.text: What does your child mostly do on screens?
questions.source: ScreenQ — content domain; DSEQ — educational vs. non-educational content

options.text: Mostly content we've picked — educational shows, specific apps
A mix — some chosen by us, some they pick themselves
Mostly whatever they navigate to — YouTube, games, autoplay
I've lost track of what they're watching — they find their own stuff

questions.text: When your child says 'I'm bored,' who reaches for a screen first?
questions.source: PSUS — family norms; SCREENS-Q — context of use

options.text: Neither — we suggest other activities or let them figure it out
They ask for a screen, and sometimes I say yes
I offer a screen before they ask — it solves the problem quickly
Boredom doesn't come up — a screen is usually already going

questions.text: Has your family's screen time quietly increased over the past few months?
questions.subtext: Not a conscious decision to watch more — just a gradual drift.
questions.source: PMUM-SF — tolerance item: screen time gradually increasing is a universal creep pattern

options.text: No — it's stayed about the same or decreased
A little — it creeps up during busy or stressful stretches
Yes — noticeably more than it was, without anyone deciding it should be
Significantly — screens have taken over more and more of the day

questions.text: What happens when screens are suddenly unavailable — dead battery, no wifi, forgot the tablet?
questions.source: PMUM-SF — withdrawal and loss of control markers

options.text: Everyone adjusts — it's not a big deal
Some complaining, but they find something else within 10 minutes
Major protests — it throws off our whole routine
It feels like a crisis — for the kids AND for me

questions.text: How hard would it be for your WHOLE family — adults included — to go screen-free for a Saturday?
questions.subtext: Not as punishment. Just: could you do it?
questions.source: DREAMER framework — family media ecology means everyone, not just the children

options.text: Totally doable — we'd enjoy it
Hard but possible with planning
Very hard — someone would cave by lunchtime
Honestly can't imagine it working

high.headline: Your home media setup is intentional
high.detail: Screens aren't freely available, background media is minimal, and you have rules that stick. Your child's screen access is shaped by deliberate choices, not default availability. Research shows that the home media environment is the strongest predictor of how much children use screens — environment shapes behavior more than willpower.
high.strength: Your home setup naturally limits screen time without requiring constant enforcement

medium.headline: Your media environment has some structure
medium.detail: Devices are around and accessible, rules are flexible, and background screens are part of the landscape some of the time. This is extremely common — most homes look like this. The research shows that tightening the environment (moving devices, firming up one or two rules) is more effective than trying to police usage in the moment.
medium.concern: A few small environmental changes — like a screen-free zone or putting the tablet in a specific spot — can shift patterns without any willpower required

low.headline: Screens are always within reach
low.detail: Multiple devices are available, background media is common, and rules haven't stuck. When screens are everywhere and always on, they become the default activity — not because anyone chose it, but because it's the easiest thing in the room. This is the area where small physical changes (moving a device, turning off the TV during meals) have the biggest impact.
low.concern: The research is clear: reducing access is more effective than restricting usage. Moving one device out of easy reach does more than adding a new time rule.

high.headline: You have non-screen strategies for the hard moments
high.detail: When you need to get things done, manage transitions, or weather a meltdown, screens aren't your first move. You've built a toolkit of other approaches — independent play, comfort, patience, distraction, or accepting the chaos. This doesn't mean you never use screens. It means they're one option among many.
high.strength: You have a diverse parenting toolkit — screens are an option, not the only option

medium.headline: Screens are one tool in your parenting toolkit
medium.detail: Sometimes you reach for a screen, sometimes you don't. It depends on the day, your energy, and what's happening. This is honest and realistic — no parent has infinite patience. What the research suggests is paying attention to which moments automatically trigger screen use, and having one backup plan for those specific moments.
medium.concern: Notice which moments you reflexively reach for a screen — that's where one alternative strategy (even an imperfect one) can break the automatic pattern

low.headline: Screens have become your go-to parenting tool
low.detail: When things get hard — you need a break, your child is melting down, you're stuck in a waiting room — a screen is the move. This isn't a moral failing. Screens work. They're fast, they're reliable, and parenting is exhausting. But it does mean your child's screen time is driven mostly by YOUR needs, not their demand for screens. That's actually useful information — it means the change is yours to make, at your own pace.
low.concern: Your child's screen time is mostly parent-initiated. That's easier to change than child-driven dependency — you're the one with the remote.

high.headline: Screen time is intentional and engaged
high.detail: You know what your child is watching, you've chosen much of it, and you're often present when they're using screens. When boredom strikes, screens aren't the first thing anyone reaches for. Research shows that co-viewed, curated content is a fundamentally different experience from solo, autoplay-driven screen time — even at the same duration.
high.strength: The quality and context of your family's screen use matters more than the hours — and yours is strong

medium.headline: Some screen time is engaged, some is background noise
medium.detail: You have a mix: sometimes you're watching together and talking about it, sometimes screens are running while you do other things, and sometimes your child is navigating on their own. The research suggests that the engaged moments are doing real good — and even small shifts toward more co-viewing and content curation have measurable benefits.
medium.concern: You don't need to co-view everything — but knowing what your child watches regularly and talking about it occasionally makes a real difference

low.headline: Screens are running on autopilot
low.detail: Your child mostly navigates their own screen experience — choosing content, handling boredom with a device, and watching without much adult involvement. This is common when screens are used for childcare time, which is exactly how many families use them. The concern isn't duration — it's that unsupervised, auto-played content is the least beneficial type of screen use for developing minds.
low.concern: You don't have to watch with them all the time — but knowing what they're consuming and occasionally joining in transforms screen time from passive to engaged.

high.headline: Your family can take screens or leave them
high.detail: Screen time hasn't crept up, unavailability doesn't cause drama, and a screen-free day is doable. This flexibility is the clearest signal that screens haven't become emotionally or logistically necessary — they're genuinely optional for your family. This is the strongest protective factor against problematic use as your child grows.
high.strength: Your family has genuine flexibility around screens — the strongest predictor of healthy long-term media habits

medium.headline: There's some screen attachment, but it's manageable
medium.detail: Screen time has probably drifted up a bit, going without would be uncomfortable but not catastrophic, and there's some protest when screens are taken away. This is the zone most families live in. The 'creep' is normal — screens are designed to be easy to reach for. Noticing it is the hard part, and you've already done that.
medium.concern: The gradual creep is the pattern to watch — it's not dramatic enough to notice day by day, but over months it shifts what feels 'normal' for everyone

low.headline: Screens have become hard to live without
low.detail: Screen time has increased significantly, unavailability causes real disruption, and a screen-free day feels impossible — for the kids and possibly for you too. When screens have reached this level of entrenchment, it's less about individual willpower and more about restructuring the environment and routines. The research on families who've successfully pulled back shows it takes about 2 weeks of consistent change for the new normal to feel normal.
low.concern: The first two weeks of pulling back are genuinely hard. After that, it gets dramatically easier. Expect resistance — it's proof the change matters, not proof it's wrong.

ready.headline: Balanced Screen Ecology
ready.subheadline: Your family has a healthy, flexible relationship with screens.
ready.explanation: Screens are part of your life, but they're not structuring it. Your home environment is intentional, you have strategies beyond screens for the hard moments, screen time is mostly engaged and curated, and your whole family can go without when needed. This doesn't mean zero screens — it means screens are a choice, not a crutch.
nextSteps: Keep doing what you're doing — consistency matters more than perfection
As your child grows, involve them in screen decisions: 'You get 30 minutes — do you want it now or after dinner?'
Check in every few months: is screen time creeping? Habits drift, and that's fine — just notice it
Talk about what they watch. Not to police it, but to stay connected to their world
ready.watchOutFor: Stressful periods (illness, new baby, work crunch) will spike screen time. That's normal. What matters is whether you recalibrate afterward, not whether you're perfect every week.
ready.encouragement: You've built a family culture where screens are genuinely optional. That's rare and valuable — and it will serve your child well as screens get more compelling in the years ahead.
ready.comparativeContext: Families who score in this range tend to have children who handle boredom well, transition off screens without conflict, and have diverse non-screen interests.

almost.headline: Leaning on Screens
almost.subheadline: Screens are playing a bigger role than you might want — and it's worth looking at where.
almost.explanation: Your family uses screens regularly, and they've quietly become the default for more moments than you probably planned. The domain breakdown below shows WHERE the lean is — it might be the environment (too many devices, too accessible), it might be parent-driven convenience (screens as your go-to for hard moments), or it might be creeping dependence. Knowing where the weight is tells you what to change.
nextSteps: Look at your domain breakdown — pick the lowest-scoring area and make ONE change there
If 'Why Screens Come Out' is low: identify your top screen-trigger moment and find one alternative for just that moment
If 'Home Media Environment' is low: move one device or establish one screen-free zone
If 'Flexibility' is low: try a screen-free evening (not a whole day — just dinner to bedtime) this week
almost.watchOutFor: Don't try to change everything at once. Pick one domain, make one adjustment, live with it for 2 weeks. Then reassess.
almost.encouragement: You're in the zone where small changes make the biggest difference. A month from now, this can look completely different — and it doesn't require a revolution, just one or two tweaks in the right spot.
almost.comparativeContext: Most families score in this range. One or two targeted changes — like a screen-free mealtime or a specific 'no screens for this' moment — typically shift the dynamic within a few weeks.
almost.retakeAdvice: Retake this quiz in 4-6 weeks after making one adjustment

not-yet.headline: Screen-Heavy Household
not-yet.subheadline: Screens are doing a lot of heavy lifting in your family right now.
not-yet.explanation: Devices are available and always on, screens are the go-to for hard moments and downtime, much of the content is unsupervised, and going without feels impossible. This is not about your child being 'addicted' — it's about your whole family's system having made screens central. The good news: the domain breakdown below shows you exactly where to start, and the research says families who make targeted environmental changes see real shifts within 2-3 weeks.
nextSteps: Start with the ENVIRONMENT, not the rules: move one device, turn off background TV, or create one screen-free zone
Pick your easiest win from the domain breakdown — whichever area feels most changeable right now
Expect 1-2 hard weeks when you start changing things. That's the adjustment period, not proof it's not working.
Look at your own screen use too — the research is clear that family-wide changes stick better than child-only rules
not-yet.watchOutFor: If reducing screen time causes extreme, multi-hour meltdowns daily for more than 2 weeks, talk to your pediatrician. Sometimes intense screen dependence signals underlying regulation challenges that deserve attention.
not-yet.encouragement: You're reading this, which means you're questioning the current pattern. That awareness is genuinely the hardest step. The research on families who successfully pulled back shows one consistent thing: they didn't do it all at once. They changed one thing, stuck with it, then changed one more.
not-yet.comparativeContext: Research shows that even families with very high screen use can shift to balanced patterns within 2-3 months of consistent environmental changes. The first two weeks are the hardest.
not-yet.retakeAdvice: Retake this quiz in 6-8 weeks after making one or two environmental changes
